Patients, EMS providers, and EMS physicians supporting all aspects of EMS through clinical leadership all deserve the finest clinical treatment protocols available. This set of clinical guidelines has been written to guide Rice University EMS providers in offering quality prehospital care.

EMS professionals should never perform emergency medical care outside of their individual scope of practice established by professional medical training, certification/licensure, and medical oversight physician authorization. When encountering patient conditions requiring care unspecified in these clinical guidelines, seek appropriate direction from on-line medical control, always delivering care with prudence and reasonable regard for safety of the patient, peers, and the public.
General Rules for Following the Clinical Guidelines
Clinical guidelines may overlap with one another. In this situation, treat the most life- or limb- threatening problem first. If that is unknown, treat the most likely underlying problem first.
When the indicated treatment changes from one guideline to another guideline, do not administer more than the maximum total dose of a medication.

Some guidelines and drug dosage ranges are taught as absolutes. However, provider judgment based on individual patient conditions must also be used in determining appropriate patient care. For any case where deviation from the guideline seems like an appropriate course of action, medical command contact with a physician medical director should be made.

Any licensed medical personnel who orders procedures beyond the scope of these clinical guidelines must accompany the patient during transport to the hospital.Specific medical devices are occasionally utilized to illustrate one method of care performance in several protocols. Rice University EMS does NOT exclusively endorse these devices for use. Devices may change and/or be updated due to product availability.When possible, medication alternatives are indicated in the clinical guidelines in light of current and anticipated future medication supply shortages affecting EMS systems throughout the United States.It is the sincere hope that these clinical guidelines will guide Rice University EMS professionals in achieving the best clinical outcome possible for each and every patient receiving their dedicated care.‌Authorization LevelThe following represents the patient care activities that are authorized to be performed by personnel as stated in the clinical guidelines. All BLS activities are authorized in a standing order to be used as needed. Authorization for ALS activities is indicated in the clinical guideline or procedure document for each intervention. 08/14/2025‌Infectious Disease Precaution RecommendationsRice University Emergency Medical Services Clinical GuidelinesIn the course of EMS care of a patient (from time of emergency services request through transport of the patient to the destination location), EMS professionals should be informed, aware, and proactive regarding practices that reduce their exposure to infectious diseases, with a goal of preventing transmission of those infectious diseases to and/or through EMS professionals.The following recommendations are general guidelines that will assist in reducing exposure to infectious diseases in the commission of EMS treatment of patients.Follow immunization recommendations from Centers for Disease Control Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices (ACIP) (e.g., Hepatitis B and Flu vaccinations)Always be prepared for isolation from body substances (blood, respiratory secretions, sputum, saliva, emesis, fecal matter).Wear examination gloves and eye protection during patient care activities.If patient conditions tolerate, reduce exposure of suspected infectious respiratory droplets by covering the patient’s nose and mouth in oxygen administration (e.g., non-rebreather mask)or with a face mask (e.g., surgical type face mask) if oxygen administration is not required.When providing airway assessment and management, maximize the functional distance between the patient’s nose and mouth and the EMS professional’s nose and mouth. The greater the possible distance, the lesser the risk of respiratory illness transmission.Wear appropriate body substance isolation (eye splash protection, mask over nose/mouth, gloves as previously noted, gown to protect personal uniform contamination) as patient suspected illness/injury may dictate.During treatment of the patient, avoid likely trajectories of bleeding, coughing, spitting, vomiting, defecating whenever possible.Exercise extremely diligent action when handling or around the handling of contaminated sharps (e.g., IV/IO needles, needle/syringe, glucometer lancets) and have appropriate sharps container readily present. Full sharps containers should be disposed of at the infectious waste collection area on campus, at the back dock of George R. Brown Hall.For all exposures, wash exposed area(s) as soon as possible with copious irrigation and/or antibacterial solution approved for that area(s) use.In the event of exposure, follow general principles as listed in Post-Exposure Prophylaxis Recommendations. Do not delay in reporting and seeking treatment for an infectious disease/body substance exposure of concern.Hand washing with soap and water should be done by all patient care providers after each call.Cleaning supplies are available in EMS responder vehicles, at RUPD, and at the Duncan EMS room. Patient care equipment should be cleaned after every call, with particular attention to frequently used items such as vital signs equipment, clipboards, and radios. Contact the Operations Lieutenant for any needed cleaning supplies.‌Post-Exposure Prophylaxis RecommendationsRice University Emergency Medical Services Clinical GuidelinesPreventing an exposure is always better than the “cure” for an exposure. Despite careful practices, EMS professionals can experience at least one concerning infectious disease exposure in a career.The following recommendations are general guidelines that can assist in post-exposure evaluation and PEP care:Wash exposed area(s) as soon as possible with copious irrigation and/or antibacterial solution approved for that area(s) use.Gather as much information about the exposure of concern as possible – what body substance (e.g., blood, saliva), what route of exposure, timing/amount of exposure, patient demographics, and any related infectious disease medical history of the patient (e.g., known HIV or Hepatitis C?).Do not delay in reporting and seeking treatment for an infectious disease/body substance exposure of concern. Regardless of time of day or day or week, seek direction from the appropriate EMS supervisor. Contact the InCharge present on the call, the EMS Captain or Senior Lieutenant, and/or the EMS Director immediately after the patient’s care can be transferred to other healthcare providers. Rice EMS Medical Command will be consulted for appropriate follow up care.Time to treatment (in hours) is of the essence to reduce transmission of infectious disease.Additional information on PEP care can be obtained at the following website:http://nccc.ucsf.edu/clinician-consultation/pep-post-exposure-prophylaxis/Complete a First Report of Injury/Illness form, located on the Rice University Risk Management website. This form should be returned to the EMS Director.‌Informed Patient Consent & RefusalRice University Emergency Medical Services Clinical GuidelinesCriteriaRefusal = when competent patient refuses treatment and/or transport to advanced health care facility after being informed of suspected medical condition, type of treatment rendered and consequences and possible risks of treatment and refusal of treatment or transportMental capacity of adult (>18 years old) patient. Capacity should be noted to include the following:Ability to communicate a choice concerning medical evaluation, treatment and/or transportAbility to understand relevant information about treatment/planAbility to appreciate the significance of the information in this circumstance, by communicating understanding of risks and benefitsAbility to use reasoning to select a choice(Pediatric) Mental competence of adult (>18 years old) caretaker as defined aboveGeneralAll personnel must have consent (either implied or informed) before treating a patient.Any adult of mental capacity or guardian may either consent to or refuse treatment/transport for themselves (adult) or patient for whom they are responsible (pediatric)Any police officer may order treatment or transportation of any prisoner in their custodyAny patient may be transported against their will if the EMT has court order for patient to receive treatment or if the patient is in the custody of a law enforcement officer.Mentally incompetent patient or patients without the capacity to refusePatients can be considered by either courts or by definition of policy may be treated under implied consent. If patient refuses to be treated/transported, RUPD may be notified to safely restrain patient.RefusalAny competent adult has the right to refuse treatment, even if that lack of treatment may result in death.Any patient refusing treatment or transport shall be informed of the possible consequences of that refusal and shall sign a refusal form.Individuals other than REMS personnel should sign as a witness the patient’s refusal, if possible.Any EMT who does not feel comfortable with a patient refusing treatment or transport because the EMT feels that the refusal may result in death or serious injury shall contact the EMS Director and/or an EMS Medical Director.Implied consent: the assumption that, in a true emergency where a patient who is unresponsive or unable to make a rational decision is at significant risk of death, disability, or deterioration of condition, that patient would agree to emergency treatment.Informed consent: consent for treatment that is given by a competent patient based on a full disclosure of possible risks and benefits.Prehospital Emergency Care, 10th Edition. Mistovich, Joseph J. Pearson Education, © 2014.All patients that REMS providers meet for an EMS call will be offered evaluation and transport to the emergency room. For patients who choose not to go to the emergency room by ambulance, a refusal form must be signed. This should be signed by the patient in most cases.Exceptions:If the patient is less than 18 years old, the patient’s parent or guardian may sign on their behalf if they are present on scene. If there is no parent or guardian on scene, the EMS provider should make a reasonable attempt to contact a parent or guardian on the phone to verify consent and refusal. If no parent or guardian is available on scene or on the phone, RUPD or a University official such as a College Master, Resident Assistant, or Athletics personnel such as a coach or trainer may be asked to sign on the minor’s behalf. In the case that no one is willing to sign on the minor’s behalf, Medical Command should be contacted for direction.A patient must be awake and alert, with a reasonable understanding of what the form states, to qualify to sign the refusal form. The EMS provider should review the information on the formwith the patient, and then ask to check the patient understands what they are signing. Patients who are unable to understand the form, recall the information on the form, and/or who are physically unable to sign the form, should be reevaluated for competency.A patient who has a physical injury to an arm or hand that would make signing painful or difficult may choose to not sign the form. RUPD or a University Official should be requested to witness the patient’s acknowledgement of the refusal of ambulance transport.In the case of a patient who refuses to sign the form, RUPD or a University Official should be requested to respond to the scene to witness that EMS offered treatment and/or transport, but the patient refused these options, and refused to sign the form.

Patients should also be requested to sign the refusal form for refusal of specific interventions. A patient with neck pain may elect to not have a cervical collar applied, for instance, and should sign the form indicating they accept liability for this action.
‌Multiple Patient Scenes / Mass Casualty Events
Rice University Emergency Medical Services Clinical Guidelines
Definitions
A multiple patient scene involves multiple patients on scene, but not more patients than can be managed by the EMS resources available on campus.
A mass casualty event involves multiple patients than cannot be managed by the EMS resources available on campus.
A victim is a person involved in an incident that does not require or request medical attention, and no apparent injuries are identified.

A patient is a person involved in an incident that either requires or requests medical evaluation, treatment, or transport. A person with an obvious injury or ailment that refuses EMS care or evaluation is still considered a patient.

Incident command at these scenes will be assigned according to the National Incident Management System (NIMS) guidelines and a unified command team consisting of representatives of police, fire and EMS should be rapidly assigned and coordinated to ensure safe, efficient and effective operations.

Below please find a general outline of NIMS guidelines for mass casualty events, focused on the medical branch tasks. As a small agency. REMS will almost always need to call for additional assistance from Houston Fire Department for any large-scale emergency event. Familiarization with campus, and an ability to bridge communications between campus resources and Houston resources will likely be the most productive role that REMS staff can fill in a large-scale emergency event. See the REMS specific notes on the side of the page for practical tips.
Scene Tasks:
Initial Size-up Actions:Park initial arriving apparatus in safe location a short distance away from the incident.

Advise dispatch:Incident location (if different from initial dispatch)REMS – request additional assistance page from Dispatch.Incident type (transportation accident, fire, etc. if different from initial dispatch)The estimated number of patients.What additional resources are needed and how many are requested.Any hazardous conditions (weather, electrical, structural, toxic chemicals, etc.).Identify a “HOT ZONE” or ”Immediate Danger Zone,” if applicableBest route & access to scene (if appropriate)Staging area location (if staging indicated).
Check in with Incident Command staff to determine your ICS role. The medical treatment and transport of injured patients will normally be done through the position of Medical
Branch Director and subordinate positions headed by Group Supervisors. However, the Incident Commander will determine which positions, if any, they feel needs to be filled.
All information about the incident should be treated as Protected Health Information (number of patients, type of incident, hospital destinations)

For all large-scale incidents at Rice, the University’s Public AffairsStaff will serve as the Public Information Officer(s) and will release information about the incident to the press/public after consulting with Incident command staff.Specific Roles and Responsibilities:

Medical Branch DirectorReports to the Operations Section Chief.Establishes the Triage, Treatment, and Transportation Areas (if indicated) and assigns individuals to the role of Group Supervisors (or Officers) for each area.Maintains adequate span of control within Medical BranchEstablish appropriate EMS communications with appropriate response elements (i.e. Staging, logistics)REMS – forward important information on scene via the InCharge or EMS Director to the Command Staff.REMS – contact a medical director to advise of campus situation. Ask for their availability for future phone calls as needed throughout the incident.Establish and maintain communications with assigned Group Supervisors (Officers)Oversee the triage, treatment, transportation and accountability of patients created by the incident.Monitors the potential or actual effect of the incident on the existing medical infrastructure and communicates such with theOperations Section ChiefDetermines resource requirements to meet the medical needs of the incident and communicates needs to the Operations Section Chief or designated response element.Determines the need for specialized medical resources and processes requests for such elements through appropriate channels.Provides situation updates and reports toREMS – consider scope of event & weather. Will additional trash cans be needed? Drinking water? Contact campus resources via dispatch to request support in these areasthe Operations Section ChiefREMS – find a place to highlight and copy campus maps for EMS transport personnel, showing the most direct route to TMC hospitals from treatment area.REMS – Some large-scale Rice Events have preplanned MCI plans including staging, ingress/egress routes, and maps.

Group Supervisor (Officer):Establishes Area to perform assigned tasksDetermine resource and staffing needs for Area of responsibility and communicates needs to Medical Branch DirectorProvides situational updates and reports to the Medical Branch DirectorEstablish communications with the Medical Branch Directors and other needed response elements.Monitors safety and welfare of patients and assigned personnelEnsures patient tracking and accountability of injured patients in assigned area.Tasks during a Mass Casualty Incident:Triage Area:

The Initial triage of patient should begin where the incident occurred, unless a hazard or other situation indicates the scene is no longer safe.For scenes with hazards or safety concerns, a Casualty Collection Point should be established at a safe location nearby, outside of the designated “HOT ZONE.”
During the triage phase, no treatment is performed. In order to efficiently and effectively treat the casualties, you must ensure you know how many patients require treatment.

Every victim or patient within an incident will be tagged with a Texas EMS Wristband and logged into the Rice EMS patient tracking software, Pulsara®. Pulsara® will be used to track all individuals associated with the incident.A Texas EMS wristband will be placed on the patient’s extremity (Left arm preferred)The patient’s name, date of birth, and primary injury will be documented.The patient’s wristband number will be entered manually or scanned using the barcode scanner.The patient will be added to the incident in Pulsara®The patient will be triaged, and their acuity (“Condition”) will be logged into Pulsara®.No Color / Unmarked: A victim that DOES NOT require medical assistanceGreen: Patients with minor injuries who can walk and follow commandsYellow: Patients who are unable to walk, but are able to follow commandsRed: Patients with life threatening injuries including altered mental status, RR ≥ 30, delayed Cap refill, or absent radial pulsesBlack: Patients who are deceased or have injuries that will not sustain lifeLink to START Triage Algorithm (Adult) and JUMPStart Algorithm (Pediatric)After the above steps have been completed, select CREATE at the bottom of the page and continue to the next patient.The CREATE button must be selected as soon as possible in order to allow others to begin documenting on the same patient channel.

Pulsara® will monitor and track the amount of patients and the number of patients in each category in real time. This information will be monitored by the Triage Group Supervisor (Officer), Medical Branch Director, and Command Staff.In the event of catastrophic failure of the communications network and Pulsara® cannot be utilized, a wristband will be attached to the patient’s extremity and their triage color will be written on their extremity, or a color-coded wristband or tape may be used.

Once established, each patient will be directed to the Treatment area based on their acuity.Ambulatory patients will be instructed to walk to the GREEN treatment area.Use discretion in allowing GREEN patients to assist in caring for critical patients while those more serious casualties are awaiting extrication to the treatment areas.

Repeat the triage process when possible and note changes in any patient’s condition.Perform a more detailed assessment, provide treatment, and update colored ribbon as appropriate while casualties are being extricated to the Treatment Area.If a victim becomes a patient, select their appropriate Condition (Green, Yellow, Red) on their Patient Channel in Pulsara®Treatment Area:

Establish a treatment area in consultation with the Medical Branch Director regarding location.Identify a large enough space to allow adequate room to triage, treat, and move casualties.Ensure the location promotes relative ease of ambulance loading and egress.

Request, assign, utilize, and oversee appropriate clinical personnel caring for patients.Assemble into crews of at least 2 personnel and usebackboards and stair-chairs to package and extricate triaged casualties into the Red, Yellow, and Green treatment areas. Patients who have been marked deceased (Black) should not be moved into the treatment area.The Treatment Sector Officer may choose to have separate personnel perform treatment once inside the Treatment Area, if available.All persons involved in the incident triaged Green are to be kept in the Green Treatment Area until thoroughlyREMS – what additional supplies will be needed?Consider utilizing non-sworn RUPD personnel for assistance in bringingadditional equipment, such as cots or special event bags, to the treatment area.evaluated. These individuals will be released at an appropriate time by the Transport Group Supervisor (Officer).Depending on the circumstances, the Green casualties may be transported early or in large groups using alternative transport means.REMS – consider optimal staging & triage locations. Consider temperature- controlled locations, ideally two or three buildings away from incident.

During the treatment phase, more patient information should be collected and logged into Pulsara®.Use a Flowchart Note to document past medical history, current injuries / complaints, or any interventions (Medications or Skills)Add a Label to identify the patient’s affiliation (College, Visitor, Staff, or Unknown)Add in Vital signs (A minimum of a GCS, Respiratory Rate, and Pulse should be documented)Use the Contact Tab to document a patient’s phone number and email (if able and time permits)If available, Add in the patient's Rice ID, State ID, or DL into the Images tab.It is acceptable and encouraged to include images of the patient and their injuries into Pulsara®. Pulsara® is HIPPA compliant.

If a patient’s condition worsens (e.g. Yellow to Red; Green to Yellow) inside the Treatment Area, update the patient’s acuity within Pulsara® and move the patient to the appropriate location in the Treatment Area.Changing the patient's acuity in Pulsara will notify the Operations and Command Staff of the change in condition.Document the change in condition and time by adding a Flowchart Note into the patient’s Pulsara channel.Transportation Area:
The Transportation Area will require the coordinated effort of several people to coordinate with the Staging and Treatment Groups, and to assist with the tracking and movement of patients.
Outside agencies that utilize Pulsara® can obtain patient information by scanning the patient’s Texas EMS Wristband.

Establish a patient loading zone.Consider a close proximity to the treatment area and how the ambulances will approach and exit the area.Establish ambulance traffic routes that prevent ambulances from having to back-up to load patients or turn around to leave the area. This makes for safer and more efficient transport operations.

Consider establishing a secondary staging area.REMS – consider if non- ambulance transport would be of assistance for green category patients.Dispatch can contact Rice Transportation to request shuttle busA staging area allows additional ambulances to wait outside of the patient loading zone to prevent a backlog or traffic jam.Work with the Staging Group Supervisor to ensure at least one ambulance is always in the loading zone.
Ensure vehicle operators stay with their ambulances to ensure as soon as patients are loaded, the ambulance leaves.
Communicate with Treatment Group Supervisor (Officer) when ambulances are available for transport. Each ambulance can only transport:One RED patient with one YELLOW or GREEN patientTwo YELLOW patents

Pulsara® will be used to track where the patient is being transported and by which EMS agency and unit. One to two people should be assigned to this task. Rice EMS will:Select the transport destination for all patients being transported by HFD or City Ambulance.Other outside agencies who are using the Pulsara® app may select their own transport destinationIn the Chief Complaint box, the EMS Agency and Unit will be documented.Ex: HFD A16 or HCEC M91

Notify the Medical Branch Director when all patients have been cleared from the scene and transported. Maintain and secure records for the Medical Branch Director and secure the patient loading area.Staging Area

A Staging Group Supervisor (Officer) will oversee the establishment and operations of the staging area. The staging area may not be required for all incidents.A staging area is a secondary location to temporarily store (“stage”) additional resources until they are neededStaging area should be large enough to contain numerous ambulances, fire apparatus, or transportation assets such as buses and vans.The staging area should be far enough from the Treatment Area that units are not prevented from leaving the area or creating a traffic jam, but close enough to loading zone to allow for short drive times.
Select and communicate a desired travel route for resources assigned to the Staging Area.This route should allow for easy access but should take units away from the impacted area.
The Staging Group Supervisor (Officer) should coordinate an orderly arrangement of arriving apparatus to allow for ease of ambulance ingress to the transport loading zone.

The Staging Group Supervisor (Officer) or the officer’s designee should maintain a log of available resources in the staging area and communicate with the Medical Branch Director the number of resource and if any more are required or have not yet arrived.

The Staging Sector Officer or the officer’s designee should assure ambulance or specialty transport crews stay with their assigned vehicles to ensure rapid availability of the asset when requested at the transport loading zone.

Delivering equipment needed in the treatment sector that is requested from staging in an organized manor with the minimum number of personnel leaving the staging area to deliver this equipment.Alternatively, all the requested equipment may be sent to the treatment area on one designated vehicle.

Assign and deploy transportation assets to the loading zone(s) at the request of the Medical Branch Director or the Transportation Group Supervisor depending on the established communication pathways.Mass Casualty Medical Communications

Medical communications during a mass casualty incident, like all other incident communications, are of critical importance and often will determine the level of effectiveness and success of the operation. Basic communication principals should be used during an incident.Use of interoperable radio channels so all agencies are able to communicate.Following the overall incident communications plan established by the Incident Commander.Establishing assigned, clear, and understood lines of communications, who will communicate with whom, for what reason, and by what method.Use of multiple and redundant means of communications including, but limited to, radio, data, phone, runners, face-to-face, and even hand signals.Preparation for communications failure and immediately switching over to one of the established redundant communication means.Ensuring communications sent receive a response of some manner to ensure the loop has been closed.

Medical communications from the scene of an MCI, depending on complexity and command structure, often involves up to three different levels of communications:Communications (internal) with other Incident Command System elementsOperations Section Chief or designee(s)Unified Command medical representativesLogistics, Planning, Admin/Finance if appropriateCommunications (internal) within the scene medical response infrastructure (Triage, Treatment, Transportation, Staging Group Supervisors)Communications (external) with local, county, or regional medical coordination entities

After assigning support positions, one of the first activities of the Medical Branch Director should be to establish redundant communications pathways within the ICS structure, subordinate Group Supervisors (Officers), and other medical response elements by:Obtaining the ICS Communication Plan (Incident Channels, etc.).Determine reporting lines and redundant means of communication with Group Supervisors (Officers).Establishing and communicating manner for all communications acknowledgments.Establish communications via radio, e-mail, or phone with outside medical coordination entitiesAdvise the ICS infrastructure of communication pathways for incorporation into the updated ICS communication plan.Harris County Mutual Aid Channels

During large-scale events involving multiple agencies, the Incident Command Team may direct you to move to a designated regional mutual aid channel. These channels are referred to as “Harris County Mutual Aid” followed by a number. (Ex: HCMA #2)Change the Zone: Harris County Mutual Aid channels are on “Zone 76”. On your radio, select ZONE and then navigate to “Zone 76”APX 7000 (Old Radios)APX N70 (New Radios)Change the Channel: Rotate the dial to the appropriate channel number.The ICS 205 Form (Radio Comms) will include a Zone and Channel number for any radio channels being utilized during an incident. Use this guide to find the channels.MCI Equipment

Rice EMS is currently carrying the Thomas Triage PacksOne pack can be found in the REMS Tahoe and the REMS ExpeditionThe packs include six colors of plastic ribbon. Each patient should receive a 6–8- inch ribbon with the appropriate color after being triaged.Patient categories are:Immediate (RED)Delayed (YELLOW)Minor (GREEN) – “Walking Wounded”Deceased or Expectant (BLACK)The pack also contains two additional color tape rolls for hazards:Orange – a contaminated patientBlue – patients have been treated with an antidotePatients will still need to be logged into Pulsara. This will not replace the online patient tracking.

Patient Destination Determination
‌Rice University Emergency Medical Services Clinical Guidelines

Rice EMS is a First Responder Agency and does not provide transportation for patients. All patients are offered ambulance transportation, and for those who refuse ambulance transportation alternative destinations may be appropriate. As a general guideline:

Undergraduate patients with a medical complaint such as flu, fever, cough/cold symptoms, abdominal pain, allergies/asthma, etc., may be seen at the Rice Health Services if appointments are available. Call Health Services (x4966) to ask about appointment availability.

Urgent Care centers, such as AFC, can see patients with similar medical complaints to Rice Health Services. Any patient with a more serious medical complaint, or requiring specialist care and/or inpatient care, should be seen at an emergency department.
University employees with minor work-related injuries can be seen at Nova Clinic with workers compensation. Risk Management should be notified if a patient seeks care at Nova Clinic.

Off campus stand-alone emergency centers, such as Methodist Emergency Care Center, are equipped to handle any medical emergency. Any patient requiring specialist care, and/or inpatient care, would have to be transferred to another facility.

Texas Medical Center has multiple hospital-based emergency departments.Ben Taub, Memorial Hermann, and Texas Children’s Hospital are Level I trauma centers, and can care for the most serious medical emergencies or traumatic injuries.Methodist Hospital and St. Luke’s Hospital are also neighboring emergency rooms capable of handling medical and traumatic injuries.Specialty CareSome patients may have a specific condition or injury that would be best treated at certain facilities. Patients with:
Burn: Memorial Hermann is best equipped for any moderate or serious burns
Chemical exposure: Memorial Hermann is best equipped for chemical exposure
Dental emergency: generally, should be seen at a hospital-based emergency department
Eye injury/condition: generally, should be seen at a hospital-based emergency department
Psychiatric emergency: Ben Taub and Methodist Hospital are able to evaluate patients in the emergency department, and also offer inpatient psychiatric care

Sexual assault: any emergency department in the TMC can provide specially trained nursing staff to care for patients who have experienced sexual assault.Ben Taub has Sexual Assault Nurse Examiners (SANE) available at all timesPediatric patients with suspected sexual assault should be evaluated at Texas Children’s Hospital or Memorial Hermann.Rice EMS does not endorse any particular health care facility.‌Rice UniversityEmergency Medical Services Clinical GuidelinesMedical Assessment & Treatment‌Medical General Assessment: Adult and PediatricRice University Emergency Medical Services Clinical GuidelinesTreatment Priorities
AssessmentSCENE SAFETYPROTECTIVE EQUIPMENTPrimary SurveySecondary Survey (when appropriate)
Primary Survey CareInitiate cardiopulmonary resuscitation if indicatedOpen airwaySupport oxygenation/ventilationSupport circulation: dysrhythmia care? rate control? hypotension care?
Ongoing CareReassess all primary careSupport oxygenation/ventilationVascular accessSecondary Survey (if able)Keep patient warm/avoid hypothermia
Appropriate DestinationGeneralApproach the assessment of medical (non-trauma) patients in A-B-C order.Airway
Evaluate the patency and mechanics of the airway.Is the patient able to oxygenate and ventilate?
Rapid intervention may be required during the assessment phase if airway patency and protection is compromised.Breathing
Expose the chest as required to accurately assess the mechanics of respiration (considering patient privacy/modesty if in public location).
Note the rate, depth, and pattern of respirations and any degree of respiratory distress or effort.
Auscultate breath sounds bilaterally.

Liberally obtain pulse oximetry readings and in patients with respiratory difficulties, waveform capnography readings (if equipped).**Waveform capnography is mandatory if an advanced airway is in place.Circulation
The adequacy of a patient’s circulation is best assessed first by evaluating their level of consciousness and mental status.
Next assess the location, rate, and character of the pulse.
Then check a blood pressure, preferably manually for at least the first reading.
Apply the cardiac monitor (if equipped) liberally.Special Considerations
Cardiac Arrest is an exception to the above order. Aggressively initiate chest compressions and search for shockable rhythms at the appropriate intervals per the Cardiac Arrest Protocol.

Many treatment decisions regarding airway management involve calculating the adult patient’s Glasgow Coma Scale score using the following table:PointsBest eyeBest verbalBest motor6------Obeys verbal orders5---Oriented, conversationalLocalizes to pain4SpontaneouslyDisoriented, conversationalWithdraws to pain3To commandInappropriate wordsFlexion (decorticate)2To painInappropriate soundsExtension (decerebrate)1No responseNo responseNo response

After addressing the A-B-C order in most medical patients, including evaluating and addressing any life-threatening conditions, minimize scene time and initiate steps needed for transport to an appropriate emergency department in any setting of a time-sensitive medical condition.

Complete a head-to-toe assessment of the patient if the patient is relatively medically stable. Obtain relevant history of past and current medical problems, medications, allergies, and physicians/hospitals used in care plans to help guide further assessment.

Reassess patients frequently, typically at least every 10 minutes, and more often if critical illness is discovered and being treated. In the situations of an unstable patient, vital signs should be assessed every 5 minutes, especially if hemodynamic changes are occurring.
Assess and treat per symptom or illness specific protocols that follow in this protocol set.Pediatric Assessment Considerations

Pediatric respiratory distress may look just like adult respiratory distress, presenting with:slowing respirations, cyanosis, accessory muscle use, paleness, nasal flaring, lethargy/listlessness, retractions – intercostal or subcostal, irritability, tachypnea, stridor, mottling, grunting

Vital signs vary with age. In general, the younger the patient, the faster the respiratory rate, the faster the heart rate, and the lower the blood pressure:The average normal systolic BP can also be estimated using: 80 + (2 x age) in years.Lower limits of normal systolic BP can also be estimated using: 70 + (2 x age) in years.

Consider abdominal aortic aneurysm for patients with pain described as tearing or shredding‌Allergic Reaction & AnaphylaxisRice University Emergency Medical Services Clinical GuidelinesAcute Urticarial Reactions may develop in patients who have been exposed to an environmental trigger, medication, or food. The reaction may be mild, including symptoms of:
Hives, rash, or an itch
Localized peripheral edema and rednessCredit: https://dermnetnz.org/topics/urticaria-an-overviewThe reaction may progress to include systemic symptoms (i.e. anaphylaxis), including:
Dyspnea, wheezing, or other respiratory complaints
Nausea and/or vomiting
Generalized edemaAnaphylaxis should be suspected in patients who experience symptoms of two or more body systems with any combination of symptoms, and/or hypotension.

Be sure to distinguish between allergic/urticarial reaction and anaphylaxis/anaphylactic shock. As stated above, anaphylaxis involves more than one body system and presents with symptoms like edema, respiratory distress, nausea/vomiting in addition to urticaria/itching. If there is a problem with airway, breathing, or circulation, anaphylaxis is likely.
Anaphylactic shock is accompanied by hypotension.

25% Dextrose solution (D25) is made by diluting 50% Dextrose (D50) with equal parts normal saline. 50mL of D50 should be mixed with 50mL of Normal saline to make D25.

Naloxone (Narcan) is intended to restore an adequate breathing pattern and is not designed to be used to “wake up” an overdose patient. Administer Naloxone in low doses until a normal breathing pattern is restored.Excited Delirium Syndrome

Excited delirium is defined as a state of extreme mental and psychological excitement, usually associated with chronic or illicit drug use, characterized by symptoms such as:Exceptional agitation, hyperactivity, and exceptional strengthHyperthermiaHostility, aggression, and paranoia

Patients are often found naked or stripping clothes to cool down due to extreme hyperthermia, often above 102°F.If safe to do so, actively cool the patient with icepacks and evaporative cooling, making sure not to induce hypothermia
Law Enforcement should be notified immediately in cases of suspected Excited Delirium.REMS members should remain a safe distance away from the patient until law enforcement has arrived.
Patients often die suddenly, immediately following cessation of resistance; therefore,don’t mistake a sudden unexpected calm for compliance

High quality CPR guidelinesThe chest compression rate should be 100-120 per minuteIf available, utilize a metronome. For the LP 15, push the CPR button on the right side of the screenSwitch compressors every 100 compressions or 2 minutes

Prioritize minimal pauses in compressionsOnly pause compressions during AED analysis and shockingLimit compression pauses to under 10 secondsDo not pause for placement of an advanced airwayDo not pause for breaths, even without an advanced airway
Consider reversible causes of cardiac arrest (Hs & Ts)Withholding Resuscitation

If a patient has a valid “Out of Hospital Do Not Resuscitate” or other Advanced Directive orders:All EMTs, Advanced EMTs, and Paramedics shall follow physician’s written “Do Not Resuscitate (DNR)” order, Texas DNR Consent form, or Advanced Health Care Directive accompanied by written statement from physiciansRequests can only be honored by bystanders if accompanied by appropriate documentationIf there is any doubt, begin CPR and immediately contact medical control

CPR should not be initiated, or be continued if initiated, by EMTs, Advanced EMTs, or Paramedics in the event of obvious death. Obvious death is defined as:Regardless of the cause of cardiac arrestNo pulse AND no spontaneous respirations AND pupils fixed (unreactive to light) AND one or more of the following:Rigor mortisDecapitationDecompositionBlunt traumatic cardiac arrestNo pulse AND no spontaneous respirations AND no shockable rhythm AND no organized ECG activity (Asystole)Penetrating traumatic cardiac arrestNo pulse AND no spontaneous respirations AND pupils fixed (unreactive to light) AND no spontaneous movement AND no organized ECG activity (Asystole)

In any of the above-mentioned and confirmed situations, cease or withhold BVM ventilations, placement of an advanced airway, defibrillation, CPR, and any medication administration as applicable to cardiopulmonary resuscitation.
Unless obvious death criteria met as outlined above, CPR and other resuscitative efforts should be initiated and delivered to promote the best chance of patient survival.

Do not pull the newborn.As the head emerges, encourage the mother not to push so that the delivery process can continue slowly and with minimal trauma to the perineal area.Gently guide the head downward (posterior) until the upper (anterior) shoulder delivers.If the cord is wrapped around the newborn’s neck, attempt to unwrap it from the neck. Prolapsed Cord

Prolapsed cord occurs when the umbilical cord presents itself outside of the uterus while the fetus is still inside. It can occur when the water breaks: with the release of amniotic fluid, the cord can follow.
Usually, the fetus will engage and compress the cord, resulting in fetal hypoxia.

EMTPlace the patient in the knee-chest position. Consider a prone knee-chest position.Palpate the cord for a pulse (excessive palpation may cause vasospasm, potentially leading to a worse outcome):If no pulse, elevate the presenting fetal part. This is generally performed by placing 2 fingers or an entire hand in the vagina to elevate the fetus off the cord.Wrap the cord in saline soaked dressing.Do not attempt to push the cord back into the vagina.‌Provide immediate transport to the closest appropriate facility while maintaining elevation of the presenting fetal part.

AEMTConsider IV access and NS administrationADULT:IV NS TKO if SBP ≥ 100 mmHg without hypotensive symptomsIV NS 250 mL bolus if SBP < 100 mmHg with hypotensive symptoms and no signs of pulmonary edemaRepeat up to 1 L NS if SBP remains < 100 mmHg with hypotensive symptoms and no signs of pulmonary edema
Presenting Limb
When faced with a newborn’s limb as the presenting part do not attempt delivery in the prehospital setting.
Breech Presentation
Breech presentation occurs when a newborn’s buttocks is the presenting part. Let the delivery occur naturally and ensure that an open airway is provided until delivery is completed.

EMTPlace the patient supine with knees widely separated. Elevate the patient’s buttocks, if needed.Allow the delivery to proceed normally while supporting the newborn with the palm of yourhand and arm to prevent explosive delivery.If the head delivers slowly or becomes trapped in the birth canal:place a gloved hand in the vagina, with the palm towards the newborn’s face utilizing a “V” technique with your fingers‌push the vaginal wall away from the newborn’s face to create a space until delivery of the head.Check the cord to ensure that it is not wrapped around the newborn’s neck.

Shoulder Dystocia

Shoulder dystocia occurs when, after normal delivery of the head, the newborn’s shoulders cannot pass through the pelvic outlet, interrupting delivery. Typically, after the head is delivered it will retract tightly against the perineum.

EMTPlace the patient supine with knees widely separated. Elevate the patient’s buttocks.Hyperflex mother’s legs into a knee-chest position (McRoberts maneuver), allowing her pubic symphysis to slide over the infant’s anterior shoulder, flattering the maternal sacrum.If McRoberts maneuver fails, also apply suprapubic pressure to displace the infant posteriorly. Apply pressure just above the pubic symphysis, not the uterine fundus.

AEMT‌Consider IV access and NS administrationADULT:IV NS TKO if SBP ≥ 100 mmHg without hypotensive symptomsIV NS 250 mL bolus if SBP < 100 mmHg with hypotensive symptoms and no signs of pulmonary edemaRepeat up to 1 L NS if SBP remains < 100 mmHg with hypotensive symptoms and no signs of pulmonary edema
‌Uterine Inversion

Uterine inversion occurs when the uterine fundus collapses into the endometrial cavity, turning the uterus partially or completely inside out. It is a rare complication of vaginal delivery, but when it occurs it is life-threatening.

EMTPlace the patient supine.If the placenta is still attached, do not remove it.Make one attempt to manually replace the inverted uterus by placing a hand inside the vagina and pushing the fundus along the long axis of the vagina toward the umbilicus.If a constriction ring is palpable, pressure should be applied to the part of the fundus nearest the ring to ease it through from bottom to top.If unsuccessful, cover any protruding tissue lightly with moist sterile dressings.

Rice University Emergency Medical Services Clinical Guidelines
Exposure to Oleoresin Capsicum (OC, pepper) spray
Services requested by RUPDPrior to scene entry, all providers must:
Use a face shield and eye protection
N95 mask should be worn
Gloves should also be worn

Minimize exposure to equipment and clothingTreatmentEMTManage CABCsObtain vital signs (apply cardiac monitor)Oxygen Administration as appropriateRemove contaminated clothing if possible and practical.Remove contact lenses if present.Place patient in a position of comfort as allowed by law enforcement.Irrigate face and eyes:Copious irrigation and time will relieve symptomsUse of running water, such as showers or hoses, is preferable to salineIrrigate for at least 10 minutes or until symptoms resideIf any open wounds have been contaminated, irrigate as described aboveAssess breath soundsIf patient complains of respiratory distress, treat per Dyspnea Guidelines. Proceed with extreme caution if patient has a history of asthma or respiratory disease.General

Individuals exposed to pepper spray may experience increased difficulty with respirations and are at risk for positional asphyxiation. Ensure that any patient with shortness of breath or other respiratory difficulty is placed in a position that allows minimal respiration effort.

Individuals exposed to pepper spray may concurrently exhibit signs of excited delirium, including but not limited to combativeness, hyperthermia, and restlessness. These individuals require immediate transport and ALS intervention. Treat these patients with symptomatic care and reference the appropriate protocols as necessary.
Additional attention is necessary to prevent the unnecessary exposure of personnel and equipment.‌Respiratory ArrestRice University Emergency Medical Services Clinical GuidelinesCriteria

The patient may still be experiencing a stroke even if the screening criteria are not met.‌Rice University Emergency Medical ServicesClinical GuidelinesTrauma Assessment & Treatment‌Trauma General Assessment: Adult and PediatricRice University Emergency Medical Services Clinical GuidelinesTreatment Priorities
AssessmentSCENE SAFETYPROTECTIVE EQUIPMENTPrimary SurveySecondary Survey (when appropriate)
Primary Survey CareControl arterial bleedingOpen airwaySeal any penetrating wounds from neck to navel
Ongoing CareReassess all primary careSupport oxygenation/ventilationVascular accessSecondary Survey (if able)Keep patient warm/avoid hypothermia

Appropriate DestinationGeneralBefore entering any trauma scene, ensure your personal safety. Do not attempt patient contact until hazards can be appropriately mitigated. In addition to scene safety, consider mechanisms of injury, number of patients, and special equipment or extrication needs.All trauma patients should be assessed utilizing primary, secondary and reassessment surveys.Primary Survey

The primary survey is to be conducted on all trauma patients. It is designed to rapidly identify life-threatening or potentially life-threatening injuries. The primary survey should be completed within 2 minutes of patient contact. The primary survey is only interrupted for life-threatening arterial bleeding, airway obstruction, or respiratory/cardiac arrest.

Primary survey interventions include airway management, sealing open chest wounds, identifying suspected tension pneumothorax, oxygen administration, and controlling any obvious external hemorrhage. Remember to expose the patient as needed to conduct an appropriate exam.

The following are steps of the primary survey:Manually stabilize the cervical spine while assessing the airway and level of consciousness.Evaluate breathing – present? rapid? normal? slow? shallow?Evaluate circulation – carotid and radial pulses present? Control external hemorrhage.Examine for deformity, contusions, abrasions, penetrations, burns, lacerations, tenderness, or swelling (“DCAP-BTLS”):HeadNeck – subcutaneous emphysema?Chest – paradoxical movement?Auscultate the chest for breath sounds in the mid-axilla bilaterally – present? equal?Examine the abdomen and pelvis for deformity, contusions, abrasions, penetrations, burns, lacerations, tenderness, or swelling (“DCAP-BTLS”).Examine the extremities for deformity, contusions, abrasions, penetrations, burns, lacerations, tenderness, or swelling (“DCAP-BTLS”), and pulse, movement, sensation.Any trauma patient with altered level of consciousness, abnormal respiration, abnormal circulation, or signs/conditions likely to lead to shock (distended abdomen, pelvic instability, bilateral femur fractures) should be rapidly immobilized and ambulance transport should be contacted after completing the primary survey. These are “LOAD & GO” patients.Secondary Survey
The secondary survey is always done enroute on critical patients.
If no critical conditions are found in the primary survey, the secondary survey may be conducted on the scene and should be completed within 5 minutes after the primary survey is completed.

The following are steps of the secondary survey:Obtain vital signs (pulse, respiratory rate, blood pressure, pulse oximetry)Obtain history of traumatic event and pertinent patient medical history (allergies, medications, past illness/injury, last oral intake)Head to toe exam – look for “DCAP-BLS” in every body area. Calculate GCS scorePerform indicated bandaging and splintingReassessment Survey
The reassessment survey is an abbreviated exam after interventions and done at least every 5 minutes for critical patients.

The following are steps of the reassessment survey:Repeat the primary surveyRepeat vital signsRepeat GCS score calculationCheck every intervention – proper placement of advanced airway? Proper placement of IV/IO?Check results of every intervention – improved oxygenation/ventilation? Improved vitals?Note: Patients who appear to have traumatic injuries may also have a medical complaint. Focused assessment, and reassessment, of every patient, medical or traumatic, should be conducted to identify all life-threatening conditions and treat as appropriate.‌Animal Bites and StingsRice University Emergency Medical Services Clinical GuidelinesTreatment Priorities
If an allergic reaction occurs, treat per Allergic Reaction and Anaphylaxis.
Make sure the scene is safe before beginning treatment.
Request assistance from RUPD and animal control if needed.
If safe, take a photo of the animal for the hospital.
If the bite/sting is on an extremity, remove any jewelry or constricting clothing.
Mark the edge of any swelling/irritation every 20 minutes.
Keep the patient calm.Animal bites carry a risk for infection and may require evaluation in the ER.
Dog and cat bites may require prophylactic treatment, especially bites to the hands, puncture wounds, and crush injuries. Cat bites are at a particularly high risk for infection.

Rabies should be suspected in animals who display symptoms such as inappetence, dysphagia, abnormal behavior, ataxia, paralysis, altered vocalization, or seizures:Skunks, racoons, and bats are commonly infected, and injuries from these animals should be seen in the ER.Small rodents such as squirrels, chipmunks, rats, and mice are rarely infected with rabies and have not been known to transmit rabies to humans.TreatmentEMTFor snake bites:For dog/cat bites:For ant bites:Elevate the injury above the level of the heart, if possible.Loosely bandage and transport to a hospital-based ER. Consider trauma center.Do not apply cold packs or tourniquets.Manage major bleeding and any immediate life threats.Thoroughly clean wounds. Warm water and soap are preferred if available.Consider transport to ER for possible disease transmission, especially if the animal was not domesticated or is showing signs of rabies. ER treatment should also be considered to assess for possible fractures, retained foreign bodies (like teeth), and ligament/tendon injury.Move the patient to a safe area and brush oﬀ any remaining ants.Wash aﬀected area with soap and water.Apply hydrocortisone cream to the aﬀected area for itching/burning.Assess for allergic reaction. Altered mental status
Evidence of drug or alcohol intoxication
Midline neck and/or back pain and/or tenderness
Focal neurological deﬁcits or symptoms
Anatomic deformity to the spine
Distracting injury or circumstance, including extreme agitation or emotional distress
Torticollis in children (may require immobilization in position found)
A communication barrier which prevents accurate assessment

Increased suspicion of spinal injury (major MVC, axial loading injuries to the spine, substantial torso injuries, falls > 10 feet, signiﬁcant facial trauma, hanging)If SMR is indicated and patient agrees to transport:

For patients who are ambulatory on scene or can safely self-extricate:Place cervical collar on patient. Direct patient to limit spine movement.Keep the patient in the position found (have the patient sit if found standing).When a transport service arrives, allow the patient to carefully move themselves to the unloaded stretcher.Secure the patient to the stretcher in a supine position or position of comfort.

For patients who are NOT ambulatory, require extrication, display altered mental status, and/or are unable to communicate reliably:Place cervical collar on patient. Direct patient to limit spine movement.Load patient onto a scoop or backboard. When a transport service arrives, use the scoop or backboard to move the patient to the stretcher.Remove the backboard or scoop once the patient is on the stretcher, maintaining in-line spinal alignment. Secure the patient to the stretcher. Transport in supine position.The patient may remain on the backboard or scoop if removing the device would otherwise delay critical interventions/rapid transport.Special considerations:
Extremes of age and the cognitive ability of the patient to understand assessment questions.
Patients ≥ 65 years old are more prone to skeletal injury with even minimal traumatic insult.
Patients must clearly understand the language spoken AND must have the cognitive ability to comprehend the answers asked in the SMR assessment.

Immobilized patients are at high risk for aspiration secondary to nausea/vomiting or blood in the mouth. Assess adequacy of respirations in all immobilized patients. Avoid placing securing devices over the abdomen of pediatric patients.
Ensure proper padding under the shoulders to maintain neutral alignment in pediatric patients.
All patient movements should be done to limit motion of the spine.
If in doubt, apply SMR and contact a Medical Director.‌Life Threatening HemorrhageRice University Emergency Medical Services Clinical GuidelinesCriteria

Life threatening hemorrhaging that cannot be controlled by direct pressure should be treated with a tourniquet (extremity injuries) and/or a hemostatic agent (trunk injuries).TreatmentEMTAEMTGeneral supportive careTrauma and Hypovolemic Shock supportive careObtain vital signs (apply cardiac monitor)Oxygen Administration and BVM ventilations as appropriateDetermine if patient is taking antiplatelet agent (e.g. Aspirin) or anticoagulant (e.g. Warfarin)Apply direct pressure as indicated using manual and/or via pressure dressingIf direct pressure is insufficient and bleeding is arterial and/or brisk:Apply topical hemostatic agent as indicatedMaintain direct pressure while using topical hemostatic agentNotify receiving EMS personnel if hemostatic agent was used and typeApply tourniquet as indicatedMultiple tourniquets may be used if bleeding continuesTourniquet should be placed as high as possible on extremity in a multi-trauma patientMonitor EtCO2 and Waveform CapnographyConsider Supraglottic Airway if indicated and only if BVM ventilations are ineffectiveObtain large-bore IV access and consider NS administrationADULT:IV NS bolus to maintain MAP > 65 mmHg, EXCEPT IF:Suspected head injuryFemale patient with suspected pregnancyAge ≥ 40 years oldKnown history of hypertension and/or coronary artery diseasePEDIATRIC:IV NS 20 mL/kg bolus if SBP < (70 + 2x age in years) mmHg and no signs of pulmonary edemaRepeat up to 60 mL/kg if SBP remains < (70 + 2x age in years) mmHg and no signs of pulmonary edema‌Tourniquet Application
Indications:Life-threatening extremity hemorrhage

Contraindications:NoneTechnique for the application of a Combat Application Tourniquet (CAT):(Note: this protocol uses the CAT to illustrate achieving extremity bleeding control using a tourniquet. Commercial tourniquets are proven more effective than ‘homemade’ devices. In the absence of a commercial tourniquet, ‘homemade’ devices may also help control bleeding.)

The CAT windlass uses a free-moving internal band to provide circumferential pressure to an injured and uncontrollably bleeding extremity. Once placed, keep the tourniquet secure but uncovered so that the bleeding site can be clearly monitored as well as the tourniquet itself. The time of tourniquet application should be written and secured to the patient on a piece of tape. Conscious patients may experience pain related to tourniquet use.

The CAT is applied over the extremity proximal to the bleeding site routing the self-adhering band around the extremity. Lower extremity wounds require feeding the strap through both sections of the buckle. Upper extremity wounds typically require less pressure to control and do not require feeding the strap through both sections of the buckle, though doing so is usually the optimal strategy. If a single slit of the buckle is used for arm wounds, the inner slit (closest to the windlass) is to be used.
In a multi-trauma patient, the tourniquet should be placed as high as possible on the extremity.
For all lower extremity wounds, pass the band through the outside slit of the buckle, utilizing the friction adaptor buckle which will lock the band in place.
Pull the self-adhering band tight and secure the band back on itself with theVelcro-adhesive strap.

Twist the windlass until the bleeding stops. This will typically be at or less than three complete rotations of the windlass. More could be required, but be careful not to exert too much torque on the windlass to avoid breakage.
Lock the rod in place with the windlass clip.
Secure the rod with the strap by pulling it tight and adhering it to the opposite hook on the windlass hook. Indicate the time of tourniquet application on tape.

If one tourniquet correctly applied does not completely control hemorrhaging, in addition to direct pressure, an additional tourniquet may be applied just proximal to the first tourniquet. For lower extremity bleeding, two tourniquets are typically required.

Once bleeding has been controlled by a tourniquet, the usual and customary practice is to leave the tourniquet in place throughout the remainder of scene care and transport to an emergency department.‌Hemostatic Agent Application
Indications:Life-threatening hemorrhage unable to be controlled by direct pressureIf extremity wound, consider tourniquet use (see above)
Contraindications:NoneTechnique for the application of a hemostatic agent (QuikClot):
Open clothing around wound. Remove any excess pooled blood, while preserving any clots already in the wound if possible.
Locate source of bleeding and pack gauze into wound directly onto bleeding source. More than one may be required.
Apply direct pressure until bleeding stops (typically within 3 – 5 minutes).
Leave QuikClot in place. Wrap to secure the product in the wound.
Notify receiving EMS/hospital personnel if hemostatic agent was used and what time it was packed in wound.‌Extremity InjuryRice University Emergency Medical Services Clinical GuidelinesCriteria

Discourage the patient from showering, but weigh the risks/beneﬁts with the patient if they desire to shower for comfort.Try to have a provider of the same gender on scene‌Consider IV access and NS administrationADULT:IV NS 250 mL bolus if SBP < 100 mmHg with hypotensive symptoms and no signs of pulmonary edemaPEDIATRIC:IV NS 20 mL/kg bolus if SBP < (70 + 2x age in years) mmHg with hypotensive symptoms and no signs of pulmonary edemaGeneral
If you suspect a patient may have been a victim of sexual assault, request RUPD to respond.

Refer the patient to the SAFE Oﬃce (713-348-3311). The navigators will assist the patient in accessing multiple resources on campus. Rice University partners with Texas Forensic Nurse Examiners to provide a forensic exam on campus in Student Health Services at no cost 24/7.

For students who would like to have a forensic exam performed, there are two oﬀ-campus options available: Memorial Hermann and Ben Taub. If the patient is under the age of 18, the patient should be evaluated at Texas Children’s Hospital. If the student wants to go to the hospital, RUPD can provide a courtesy escort. A SAFE Oﬃce navigator is available to accompany the student to the hospital if desired. Be sure to oﬀer this service to the patient. Please note that forensic exams are also available to students who experienced domestic/dating violence.

To access these services after hours, call 713-348-3311 and ask to speak with the Director of the SAFE Oﬃce. Share that it is an emergency. The answering service will connect with the Oﬃce.SplintingRice University Emergency Medical Services Clinical GuidelinesCriteria

No contraindications for use.TreatmentEMTcompatible with LP15 and must be replaced with LP15 pads.Check for consciousness, airway patency, breathing, pulse (CABC)If determined that patient meets all qualiﬁcations for use of AED, turn on AED.Apply AED deﬁbrillation pads. Follow illustrations on deﬁbrillation pads for correct pad placement.Avoid overlapping pads over one another.Avoid placing pads over implanted pacemakers and/or deﬁbrillators.PediatricAEDs are NOT indicated in patients under 1 years old, utilize manual deﬁbrillation with the LifePak 15‌If the patient is between 1 and 8 years old or under 25 kg, use the Infant/Child deﬁbrillation padsIf Infant/Child deﬁbrillation pads ae not available, place the Adult deﬁbrillation pads on the posterior and anterior chest.Follow AED visual and voice prompts in conjunction with chest compressions.Utilize the appropriate protocol for the resuscitation of cardiac arrest patientsMinimize pauses in chest compressionsConsider possible reversible causes of cardiac arrest and treat where appropriateHypoxia: adequate oxygenation and ventilation with 100% oxygenAcidosis: adequate oxygenation and ventilation with 100% oxygenTrauma: Rapid transport to a trauma centerIf a Lifepak 15 becomes available and will be used for deﬁbrillation:Adult Lifepak CR2 and CR+ AED pads are compatible with the LP15 monitor. When checking off the AED at the start of a shift or an event, the following should be checked:One set of adult pads (not expired)Device powers on when opened and voice prompts can be heard. Battery indicator flashes greenGeneral

In this setting, the most important thing is to conﬁrm that the patient is unresponsive,unconscious, not breathing normally, and pulseless. If uncertain of any of these qualities, perform a sternal rub to determine responsiveness and consciousness.

In an emergency resuscitation setting that required the use of an AED, do not interrupt or pause chest compressions unless absolutely necessary. For example, continue toprovide chest compressions while another operator is applying deﬁbrillation pads, powering on the monitor, selecting appropriate energy and charging the device.HOWEVER: Do NOT continue to provide chest compressions when the AED is discharging or deﬁbrillating.

Orientation

AED usageTurn on LP15Retrieve Defibrillation Pads from the right side zippered pocketConnect pads to the therapy cableAttach pads to patientPress Analyze, LP15 will enter automatic modeFollow promptsTo cancel at any time, press the speed dialDuring compression times, pressing the CPR button will silence the metronomePressing the Energy Select buttons will convert the monitor into manual operation mode (for ALS providers only)Note: Options is not available in AED mode

Routine Vitals MonitoringTurn on LP15Attach SpO2 monitor to finger, SpO2 will appear on Channel 2Attach BP cuff to arm, press NIBPContinue to monitor vitals, press NIBP as desired to get blood pressure readingsSee “General” to print vitals

If dashed lines appear, try again, orUse the speed-dial to select SpO2 on the left sideSelect ParameterSelect SpCOPress HomeValue will appear for ten seconds

3-Lead EKGTurn on LP15Retrieve electrodes from right-most pocketAttach electrodes to sensors, then to patientLA – Left ArmRA – Right ArmLL – Left LegRL – Right LegPlace medially, proximal to the most distal major joint (ankle, wrist)Advise patient to remain still and uncross legs if crossedEKG will appear on Channel 1To generate a rhythm strip, press Print to begin printing, press again to end

To change view optionsFor Channel 1Press LeadUse speed-dial to select desired leadPress SizeUse speed-dial to select desired sizeFor other channelsUse speed-dial to select desired channelUse speed-dial to select desired lead/trend/waveform and sizePress the Home icon to return
To record eventsPress EventsUse the speed-dial to select desired eventEvents will record in the code summary

Rice University Emergency Medical Services Clinical Guidelines
Symptomatic 2nd Degree AV Block Type II
Symptomatic 3rd Degree AV Block

Asymptomatic BradycardiaProcedure (Lifepak 15)Maintain standard ECG monitoringApply Quik-Combo pads at chest wall locations illustrated on pads. Dry severe diaphoresis and remove excessive chest hair prior to placement.Connect Quick-Combo pads to Lifepak 15.Advise patient of impending therapy.‌Power on the pacing function by pressing the PACER button.Ensure triangular “sense” markers are above each QRS complex. Ensure proper connection if they do not appear. If “sense” markers are present for only some QRS complexes, adjust ECG size or select an alternate monitoring lead to achieve proper tracking.Set pacing rate at 60 paces per minute using either the RATE switch or the SPEED DIAL.Set pacing current at minimum level achieving both electrical AND mechanical capture. Deliver electrical pacing current using either the CURRENT switch or the SPEED DIAL.Do not use the pause button unless directed by medical control. Holding the pause button will decrease pacing rate by 25% while it is depressed.If pacing therapy termination is required, power off the pacing function by pressing the PACER button.ConsiderationsIf ventricular fibrillation or pulseless ventricular tachycardia occurs, pressing the yellow CHARGE button will automatically stop pacing. Proceed with defibrillation.If monitoring leads become detached, pacing continues but in non- demand mode. During this mode, the patient will receive pacemaker activity at the set rate regardless of any intrinsic beats the patient may have. Reattach the monitoring leads to reestablish demand pacing.If the Quik-Combo pads get detached at any time, an alarm will sound. During this disconnection, the pacing function will resume but current will be set automatically at 0 mA. Current will remain at 0 mA until pads are reconnected and the current is manually increased back to its original level.Electrical capture is demonstrated by a QRS complex after each pacer spike followed by a distinct, broad T-wave. Mechanical capture is demonstrated by a palpable pulse after each pacer spike. Ensure that both electrical capture and mechanical capture are achieved.Pacing Pads should ideally be placed on the anterior and posterior chest.Synchronized CardioversionRice University Emergency Medical Services Clinical GuidelinesCriteria
Unstable, symptomatic tachycardia:ADULT: HR > 150 bpmPEDIATRIC: HR > 180 bpm AND afebrile
AND hemodynamic compromise:ADULT: SBP < 100 mmHgPEDIATRIC: SBP < (70 + 2x age in years) mmHgContraindications
Stable tachycardia
Normal sinus rhythm
Bradycardia

Ventricular fibrillation/pulseless ventricular tachycardiaProcedure (Lifepak 15)Power ON (figure 1)‌Attach patient ECG cable and ECG electrodes.Select lead with the greatest QRS complex amplitude positive or negative deflection (figure 2).Press SYNC. The SYNC mode message appears in the message area when SYNC is active (figure 3).Observe the ECG rhythm. Confirm that a triangle marker appears near the middle of each QRS complex (figure 4).If the markers do not appear or are displayed in the wrong location (for example, on the T wave) adjust the ECG size or select another lead.Connect the therapy electrodes to the therapy cable and confirm cable connection to the monitor.Prepare the patient’s skin and apply therapy electrodes to the patient in the anterior-lateral position (figure 6).Press ENERGY SELECT or rotate the SPEED DIAL to select the desired energy (figure 7). Begin at 100J energy. If unstable tachydysrthymia persists, repeat synchronized cardioversion at escalating energy settings of 200J, 300J, 360J. For pediatric synchronized cardioversion, consult medical command for treatment plan and energy settings.Press CHARGE. While the monitor is charging a charging bar appears and a ramping tone sounds, indicating the charging energy level. When the monitor is fully charged, the screen displays the available energy (figure 8).Make certain that all personnel stand clear of the patient, bed, and any equipment connected to the patient.Confirm ECG rhythm. Confirm available energy. Prior to delivering synchronized cardioversion, it is essential to ensure that the SYNC mode message continues to appear. Failure to deliver a “synchronized” cardioversion in this setting could cause ventricular fibrillation arrest in the patient (figure 9).Press and hold the SHOCK button on the monitor until the energy delivered message appears on the screen (figure 10). NOTE: to disarm (cancel the charge), press the SPEED DIAL. The energy disarms automatically if shock buttons are not pressedwithin 60 seconds, or if the energy selection changes after charging begins.Observe patient and ECG rhythm. Repeat procedures starting from step 4 if necessary.

Infuse medication per protocolVenous Access: IntravenousRice University Emergency Medical Services Clinical GuidelinesAEMT / ParamedicCriteriaVascular access for intravenous administration of crystalloid fluids in hypotension and/or volume insufficiencyVascular access for intravenous administration of medications for a multitude of medicinally indicated effectsVascular access in a patient with an increased potential for needing either of the above indicationsContraindicationsNone absolutely, though despite aseptic technique and using sterile angiocatheters, there is always a risk of introducing infection when the skin integrity is violated. Apply IV tourniquet proximal to proposed vascular access site.
Clean insertion site with ChloraPrep®, Betadine®, or alcohol prep.
Stabilize vein in place by applying gentle traction on vein distal to point of entry.
Puncture the skin with the bevel of the needle upward about 0.5 - 1 cm from the vein and enter the vein from the side or from above.
Note blood return and advance the catheter over the needle.
Remove needle and connect IV line. Note: venous blood for laboratory work may be drawn with syringe before connecting IV line.
Release IV tourniquet.
Open IV tubing clamp full to check flow and placement, then slow rate to TKO or as indicated by applicable treatment protocol.
Secure catheter and tubing with tape or commercial device in a manner that reduces traction upon the catheter.
Recheck IV patency periodically to minimize occurrence of unrecognized fluid/medication extravasation.
External Jugular Vein – for peripheral venous access in a patient in extremis only.
Anatomical landmarks, including the vein, must be visible – no “blind” sticks. Avoid multiple attempts and avoid attempts on both sides – use IO access prn.

Position the patient supine, head down (this may not be necessary or desirable if congestive heart failure or respiratory distress present). Turn patient's head to opposite side from procedure. (Maintain cervical spine alignment if cervical spinal injury suspected; do not attempt external jugular vein cannulation in suspected cervical spine injury patients.)
Expose vein by having patient bear down if possible, and "tourniquet" vein with finger pressure just above clavicle.
Clean insertion site with ChloraPrep®, Betadine®, or alcohol prep.
Stabilize vein in place by applying gentle traction on vein distal to point of entry.
Align the cannula in the direction of the vein, with the point aimed toward the shoulder on the same side.
Puncture skin over vein first, then puncture vein itself. Use other hand to traction vein near clavicle to prevent rolling.

Proceed as with extremity vein. ‌SAM IO® System

Assemble the following materials.Driver with needle set based on patient size and weight:PINK: 15 mm for 3-39 kg (non-existent to limited overlying adipose tissue)BLUE: 25 mm for ≥ 40 kg (minimal to moderate overlying adipose tissue)YELLOW: 45 mm for ≥ 40 kg (moderate to excessive overlying adipose tissue)ChloraPrep®, Betadine®, or alcohol wipeExtension set (90)Saline flush syringeSAM IO® StabilizerNeedleVISE® sharps

Locate the insertion site.Proximal tibia sitePalpate patella.Palpate tibial tuberosity approximately two finger widths below patella in adults and adolescents, or one finger width below patella in smaller pediatrics.The insertion site is one finger width medial to tibial tuberosity in the tibial plateau.
Clean the insertion site with alcohol wipe, or preferably with ChloraPrep® or equivalent swab.
Prime infusion set, attach the needle assembly to the driver, and remove the safety cap from the needle assembly. Do not touch uncapped, sterile components of the needle assembly.

Access the intraosseous space.Stabilize anatomy near the insertion site with non-dominant hand.Position driver at insertion site with needle at a 90 angle to the surface of the bone.Use the driver to insert the needle through the skin and adipose tissue at the insertion site until you feel the needle tip encounter bone. Ensure that ≥ 5 mm of catheter (at least the first black line on proximal catheter) is visible above the skin before attempting intraosseous insertion.Continuously actuate (repeatedly compress) the driver’s trigger assembly, while applying gentle, steady downward insertion pressure to achieve controlled entry. Use minimal (gentle) steady downward insertion pressure. Allow needle assembly tip rotation to penetrate compactbone. Discontinue trigger actuation when a subtle “give” or “pop” is appreciated, indicating needle assembly entry into the medullary space.Once the bone cortex feels encountered, ensure that ≥ 5 mm of catheter (at least the first black line on proximal catheter). If at least one 5 mm mark line is not visible, a longer needle will be required to achieve usable intraosseous access.Remove the stylet by stabilizing the needle assembly hub while retracting (lifting off) and disconnecting the driver. The stylet will remain attached to the driver. While holding the driver, guide the stylet into the provided NeedleVISE® or appropriate sharps containment device and disconnect the stylet from the driver.Apply sterile SAM IO® Stabilizer carefully over catheter and against skin. Attach primed extension set to catheter hub, firmly secure by twisting clockwise. Do NOT attempt aspiration of blood or marrow via the catheter. Pulling marrow into the catheter may clog the catheter and prevent its use for fluid and/or medication administration.Confirm proper catheter placement using a combination of the following signs:IO catheter rests at a 90 angle and feels firmly in bone when grasping hub.
Blood-tinged marrow oozes spontaneously from hub (may often be absent, yet the catheter is still correctly placed).
Fluid and medication administration is possible without significant resistance and without extravasation.

Flush SAM IO® catheter with 10 mL normal saline. Medication administration is given in the same dosing as with IV administrations. Fluid administration will require the use of a pressure infuser on the IV fluid bag. Due to the increased pressure of the marrow space, IV fluid will not infuse without assistance of the pressure infuser. Inflate pressure infuser until IV fluid is seen infusing with constant flow. Monitor for extravasation and monitor for need to reinflate pressure infuser. Fluid delivery rate may be as high as 1 liter per hour.

In determining the site for IO access, consider knowledge of the anatomy, prior training, and comfort in accessing that particular site, and how IO access at that site may or may not interfere with other care events (e.g., use of the humeral head site for medication administration in cardiac arrest could disrupt the continuity of chest compressions).
