Airway Assessment
Rice University Emergency Medical Services Clinical Guidelines
In order to assess a patient’s airway, there are several principles that must be followed in order to adequately determine if any interventions are needed:
Use the least invasive method of airway management appropriate to the patient
Position the airway that provides the most appropriate accessUse a head tilt-chin lift for medical patientsUse jaw thrust maneuver for trauma patients with suspected C-spine injures / precautions
Only use an airway management method that you are credentialed to perform
Patients may require frequent suctioning in order to keep the airway clear of debris

Monitor the patient continuously in order to ensure that oxygenation and/or ventilations are effectiveUse supplemental oxygen via nasal cannula (NC), non-rebreather mask (NRB), or bag-valve mask (BVM) as necessary

Remember the following important concepts:‌Patency: Open and clear the airway by looking for foreign substances, blood, vomitus, or tongue obstruction. Suction, if necessary, to clear the airway and/or consider repositioning the patient’s airway.Ventilation: Determine the volume / amount of air the patient is able to inhale and exhale in a given time.Waveform capnography provides effective real time measurement of ventilation.Oxygenation: Determine the amount of oxygen the patient is able to convey to the circulation for tissue/organ perfusion.Pulse oximetry may be used in this case to help assessment. Rember that pulse oximetry readings are delayed.Important Considerations:

The above guidelines are the approach to typical medical and trauma-related airway problems. They assume the treating EMS professional is skilled in the various procedures appropriate for their scope of practice.
Advanced airway procedures should only be attempted if clinically indicated after less invasive measures fail or are futile to attempt. Individual cases may require modification of these protocols.
Airway management decisions and actions should always be thoroughly documented in the patient care report.

Intoxicated (either by alcohol or drugs), trauma (especially head trauma) or altered mental status patients require careful monitoring of the airway. For these patients, be prepared to perform interventions as symptoms of respiratory distress may have a sudden onset.Airway SuctioningRice University Emergency Medical Services Clinical GuidelinesIndications:

Vomitus, food, or other foreign liquid material in the airway

Technique:
Open the airway and inspect for visible foreign materialFor trauma patients, use the jaw thrust method

Remove large or obvious foreign bodies with gloved hands.‌Sweep ﬁnger ACROSS the posterior pharynx and clear the visible material outof the mouthDo not perform blind ﬁnger sweeps of the airway. This may lodge theobstruction further into the airway
Turn on suction machine

Suction the oropharynxAttach appropriate tip to the suction unit (French catheter vs DuCanto tip)Oxygenate and/or ventilate the patient prior to this procedure, as neededInsert the tip into the oropharynx under direct vision, with a sweeping motion.Do not suction for longer than 10 seconds.Continue intermittent suction interspersed with active oxygenation by mask. Use positive pressure ventilation if needed.If suction becomes clogged, dilute by suctioning water or normal saline to clean the obstructed tubing. If suction clogs repeatedly, use connecting tube alone, or manually remove large debris.
Important Considerations:

In most situations, limit the suction time to no longer than 10 seconds. However, this precaution should NOT be followed when vomitus or other material continues to well up and completely obstruct the airway. In this case, suctioning must be continued until an airway is reestablished, with intermittent oxygenation and ventilation performed to avoid prolonged lack of oxygen.

When possible, have a container of water or normal saline at hand before beginning suctioning as it may require frequent rinsing of the catheter and tubing. Use gauze to remove large material from the end of the catheter.Equipment Notes:

Rice EMS uses the Laerdal Suction Units. These units operate off battery power and should be recharged regularly. To check the battery power, turn on the device. If the battery indicator light (next to the power button) shows yellow, the unit needs to be recharged.

‌Blood Glucose Analysis
Rice University Emergency Medical Services Clinical Guidelines
Blood glucose analysis should be considered for any patient with:Altered mental statusSuspected strokeSyncope or near syncopeSuspected drug or alcohol overdose
Any ill infant should have a blood glucose analysis
Assemble equipment. Insert single use test strip into meter with clear blood slot facing away from meter. Meter will turn on.

When blood drop symbol flashes, obtain drop of blood from fingertip. Choose whichever finger is least calloused. Apply pressure to finger to help increase blood flow. Clean fingertip with alcohol pad without contaminating area. Allow area to dry.

Hold finger and firmly place new, sterile lancet off center on fingertip. Firmly press lancet to puncture fingertip. Wipe first drop of blood with sterile gauze and touch next drop of blood to clear window of test strip.
When flash is observed on test strip, enough blood has been added to test strip. Record value on glucometer and properly dispose of all contaminated supplies.
If BGL analysis is < 60 mg/dL with indicated symptoms, proceed with hypoglycemic protocol outlined in Altered Mental Status.
Equipment Notes

REMS currently uses the Assure® Prism glucometers. The chip-like end (top) of the test strip should be inserted into the glucometer, in the same orientation shown below. The narrowed end (bottom) of the test strip should be used for blood drop collection. The clear chamber near the blood drop collection end must be filled with blood to have a usable glucometer reading. If the display reads error, a new strip must be used, and the analysis should be reattempted.

Revised 2025
Fire Extinguisher Ratings
Class A Extinguishers will put out ﬁres in ordinary combustibles, such as wood and paper.
Class B Extinguishers should be used on ﬁres involving ﬂammable liquids, such as grease, gasoline, oil, etc.
Class C Extinguishers are suitable for use on electrically energized ﬁres.
Types of Fire Extinguishers

Dry Chemical extinguishers are usually rated for multiple purpose use. They contain an extinguishing agent and use a compressed, non-ﬂammable gas as a propellant. These are the most common ﬁre extinguishers found on campus.

Halon extinguishers contain a gas that interrupts the chemical reaction that takes place when fuels burn. These types of extinguishers are often used to protect valuable electrical equipment since they leave no residue to clean up. Halon extinguishers have a limited range, usually 4 to 6 feet. The initial application of Halon should be made at the base of the ﬁre, even after the ﬂames have been extinguished.

Carbon Dioxide (CO2) extinguishers are most effective on Class B and C (liquids and electrical) ﬁres. Since the gas disperses quickly, these extinguishers are only effective from 3 to 8 feet. The carbon dioxide is stored as a compressed liquid in the extinguisher; as it expands, it cools the surrounding air. The cooling will often cause ice to form around the “horn” where the gas is expelled from the extinguisher. Since the ﬁre could re-ignite, continue to apply the agent even after the ﬁre appears to be out.
Water extinguishers contain water and compressed air and should only be used on Class A (ordinary combustibles) ﬁres.
Revised 2025
‌Hazardous Materials Response

This protocol contains generally accepted principles related to EMS response and activity related to suspected or actual hazardous materials incidents where an exposure has occurred. The overriding principle is safety, with an emphasis on minimizing, preferably preventing, further hazardous materials exposure and related illness.

Specific practices for individual hazardous material substances are beyond the capability of a general protocol and the EMS provider should consult hazardous materials specialists (Rice University Environmental Health Safety and Lab Operations, and/or Houston Fire Department) for assistance.
Rice Environmental Health Safety and Lab Operations (EHSLO)
(713)-348-4444, (http://safety.rice.edu)

Members of the Environmental Health Safety and Lab Operations team are experts in Fire, Life, and Laboratory Safety (including biological, chemical, laser, and radiation safety). The team is on campus M-F, 7a-5p, and is also available for phone consultation overnight and on weekends. Contact Dispatch to request Safety to respond to any incident on campus involving hazardous materials. If the call is overnight or on weekends, Safety can also be contacted via dispatch for assistance. The Safety team member will assist on scene with containing any hazardous materials as appropriate, and/or with evacuation if needed. If biological or chemical substances are involved, the Safety team member will likely be able to assist with information about the substance, and/or locating the appropriate Safety Data Sheet (SDS). Information about any exposure, condition, or injury to a patient should be shared with Safety team members if it will be helpful to ascertain appropriate treatment for the patient, and/or for provider safety from possible exposure.
Houston Fire Department:

Houston Fire Department (HFD) should be contacted for any large-scale incident involving suspected exposure to any hazardous material. This could include a large quantity of a hazardous material, on the person or clothing and/or multiple people exposed who are experiencing symptoms from the exposure.
HFD has the capabilities and resources to decontaminate patients and safely transport them to the appropriate facility as well as the resources to contain a large-scale spill or potential exposure.

Rice’s Safety Team (EHSLO) should be consulted in person and/or via phone for any hazardous materials incident on campus. This team knows campus labs and safety procedures and is the most fluent on hazardous materials on campus. However, do not delay in contacting dispatch to request HFD for any large-scale incident, or suspected hazardous materials exposure to single or multiple patients.
Provider safety, and patient safety, should always be the priority.
Additional Resources about Hazardous Materials for EMS Providers

The Emergency Response Guidebook can be found in the MCI bag inside the Rice EMS responder vehicles, online, or as an app. This book contains most industrial chemicals transported on a large scale. It will not contain all of the chemical information on materials used on campus. (https://www.phmsa.dot.gov/hazmat/erg/emergency-response-guidebook-erg)

WISER (Wireless Information System for Emergency Responders) is a system to assist emergency responders in hazardous materials incidents and is sponsored by the US National Library of Medicine. (http://wiser.nlm.nih.gov)

The National Institute for Occupational Safety and Health (NIOSH) Chemical Hazards Pocket Guide provides a concise source of general industrial hygiene information for workers, employers, and occupational health professionals. (http://www.cdc.gov/niosh/npg/pgintrod.html)
Texas Poison Control Center is also a useful resource. Call 1-800-222-1222.

When responding to individuals in hazardous materials environments, a real danger exists that EMS providers, public safety apparatus, and hospitals may be unable to effectively function if not protected from this contamination. Appropriate efforts must be made to protect the already apparent patient(s), responding public safety professionals, at-risk citizens, and the emergency health care system from further contamination. EMS treatment for any suspected patient(s) should not be attempted until appropriate protective measures can be accomplished. Suspected patient(s) should be limited in their movement until it is clear that the patient is determined not to pose a contamination threat by the appropriate authority (Safety and/or HFD specialists).
Initial Response to Suspected Hazardous Materials Incident

Park in an anticipated safe area (typically uphill/upwind) unless otherwise directed by hazardous materials specialists responding or already on scene. Anticipate additional responders (Safety, RUPD, HFD, etc.) to the scene and leave space as appropriate.

Determine and advise dispatch of the following (if not previously known):Exact location of the incidentType of incident (exposure, fire, etc.)Identification/nature of the hazardous materials, if knownApproximate number of patients (actual number preferred if known)Additional resources needed (Safety, HFD hazardous materials resources, number of ambulances, etc.).

DO NOT rush into a suspected hazardous/contaminated situation until appropriate safety measures are accomplished. Generally accepted safe practices include:Do not park directly in front of a building with a suspected hazardous materials release.Tell people approaching a lab or scene to stay outside until the appropriate specialists (Safety, and/or HFD specialists) determine the scene is not hazardous to others.Designate a refuge area for victims already inside the scene who may be exposed but are not symptomatic.

If the material is spilled inside of a laboratory keep the door closed. The laboratory is designed to exhaust the air 4-8 times an hour. Leaving the door open interferes with the design exhaust. It is usually not necessary to clean up a spill immediately. Patient safety should be the first priority. The laboratory will contain the spill and prevent the vapors from getting through the buildings as long as the power is on to the building and the door remains closed.
Additional safety considerations:

Whenever possible, disposable medical equipment should be used to avoid contamination of equipment. Responders should be limited to essential personnel, and consideration should be taken to limit the amount of equipment (medical equipment, radios/pagers, golf carts, etc) used for the scene.

After decontaminated patients have been treated and/or transported to the emergency department, the EMS providers (and any other first responders) should be formally evaluated by emergency health care providers at an emergency department if exhibiting unusual signs or symptoms consistent with hazardous materials exposure after participating in the incident.

Laboratory Safety Training classes are available through the Rice Environmental Safety Department Staff. It is recommended that you take these classes once a year to familiarize yourself with the university safety procedures and better understand laboratory design. Sign-up is available through the safety.rice.edu website.
